contextId.information: Here "life" is a metaphor for causing everything to live. AT: "The one who is called the Word is the one who caused everything to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Light" is a metaphor that means God's revelation. AT: "he revealed to us the truth about God as a light reveals what is in the darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that life was the light of all men

contextId.information: Here "light" is a metaphor for the revelation of God in Jesus. AT: "show how Jesus is like the true light of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "light" is a metaphor that represents Jesus as the true revelation of God. AT: "like a true light" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "children" is a metaphor that represents our relationship to God, which is like children to a father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a metaphor which refers to Jesus. He is the one who reveals what God is like. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The task of "untying his sandals," which is the work of a slave or servant, is a metaphor. John is saying that he does not deserve to do even the most unpleasant work of a servant for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the strap of whose sandal I am not worthy to untie

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that represents God's perfect sacrifice. Jesus is called the "Lamb of God" because he was sacrificed to pay for people's sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is a metaphor that represents God's perfect sacrifice. Jesus is called the "Lamb of God" because he was sacrificed to pay for people's sins. See how you translated this same phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:29|1:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "consume" points to the metaphor of "fire." Jesus' love for the temple is like a fire that burns within him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Jesus is referring to his own body as the temple that will die and come back to life three days later. Translate this in a way that describes tearing down and rebuilding a building. Jesus is not commanding his disciples to tear down the actual temple building. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up

contextId.information: The word "kingdom" is a metaphor for the rule of God. AT: "place where God rules" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
There are two possible meanings: 1) "baptized in water and in the Spirit" or 2) "born physically and spiritually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: born of water and the Spirit

contextId.information: Here the "bride" and "bridegroom" are metaphors. Jesus is like the "bridegroom" and John is like the friend of the "bridegroom." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The bride belongs to the bridegroom

contextId.information: Jesus uses the metaphor "living water" to refer to the Holy Spirit who works in a person to transform and bring new life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the word "fountain" is a metaphor for life-giving water. AT: "the water that I will give him will become like a spring of water in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the water that I will give him will become a fountain of water in him

contextId.information: Here "food" is a metaphor that represents "obeying God's will." AT: "Just as food satisfies a hungry person, obeying God's will is what satisfies me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My food is to do the will of him who sent me and to complete his work

contextId.information: The words "fields" and "ripe for harvest" are metaphors. The "fields" represent the non-Jewish people or Gentiles. The words "ripe for harvest" mean that the Gentiles are ready to receive the message of Jesus, just as fields are ready to be harvested. AT: "look up and see these non-Jewish people! They are ready to accept my message, just like crops in the fields are ready for people to harvest them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: look up and see the fields, for they are already ripe for harvest

contextId.information: The words "sows" and "harvests" are metaphors. The one who "sows" shares the message of Jesus. The one who "harvests" helps the people to receive the message of Jesus. AT: "One person plants the seeds, and another person harvests the crops." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "lamp" is a metaphor. John displayed God's holiness in the same way a lamp gives light. AT: "John was like a lamp that was burning and shining" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: John was a lamp that was burning and shining

contextId.information: To "set a seal" on something means to place a mark on it to show to whom it belongs. This means that the Son belongs to the Father and that the Father approves of him in every way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has set his seal on him

contextId.information: The "true bread" is a metaphor for Jesus. AT: "The Father gives to you the Son as the true bread from heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
contextId.quote: it is my Father who is giving you the true bread from heaven

contextId.information: Through metaphor, Jesus compares himself with bread. Just as bread is necessary for our physical life, Jesus is necessary for our spiritual life. AT: "Just as food keeps you alive physically, I can give you spiritual life." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am the bread of life

contextId.information: Just as bread is necessary for our physical life, Jesus is necessary for our spiritual life. AT: "I am the one who is like true bread." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:35|6:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Just as bread is necessary for our physical life, Jesus is necessary for our spiritual life. AT: "Just like food that keeps you alive physically, I can give you spiritual life that lasts forever." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:35|6:35]].  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am the bread of life

contextId.information: Here the phrases "eat the flesh" and "drink his blood" are metaphors that show how trusting in Jesus, the Son of Man, is like receiving spiritual food and drink. AT: "receive the Son of Man just like you receive food and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood

contextId.information: The phrases "eats my flesh" and "drinks my blood" are metaphors. Just as one requires food and drink in order to have physical life, those who trust in Jesus will have spiritual life. AT: "whoever trusts me for their spiritual food and drink will have eternal life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has everlasting life

contextId.information: The words "true food" and "true drink" are metaphors that mean Jesus provides spiritual food and drink to those who trust in him. Receiving Jesus in faith provides everlasting life the same way food and drink nourish the physical body. AT: "I am truly spiritual food and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my flesh is true food ... my blood is true drink

contextId.information: The "bread" is a metaphor for Jesus, who has come from heaven. AT: "I am like bread that has come from heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This is the bread that has come down from heaven

contextId.information: This is a metaphor. Those who trust in Jesus for their spiritual life are like those who rely on physical bread or food for their physical lives. AT: "Whoever trusts in me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the word "thirsty" is a metaphor that means one's great desire for the things of God, just as one "thirsts" for water. AT: "Those who desire the things of God like a thirty man desires water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The "rivers of living water" is a metaphor that represents the life that Jesus provides for those who are spiritually "thirsty." AT: "spiritual life will flow like rivers of water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: rivers of living water will flow

contextId.information: Here the "light" is a metaphor for the revelation that comes from God. AT: "I am the one who gives light to the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am the light of the world

contextId.information: The "light of life" is a metaphor for the truth from God that gives spiritual life. AT: "truth that brings eternal life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the word "slave" is a metaphor. This implies that "sin" is like a master for the one who sins. AT: "is like a slave to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "father" is a metaphor for the one who originates all lies. AT: "he is the one who created all lies in the beginning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "day" and "night" are metaphors. Jesus is comparing the time when people can do God's work to daytime, the time when people normally work, and nighttime to when they cannot do God's work. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "light" is a metaphor for the true revelation of God. AT: "the one who shows what is true just as light allows people to see what is in the darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "seeing" and "blindness" are metaphors. Jesus distinguishes between people who are spiritually blind and physically blind. AT: "so that those who are blind spiritually, but who want to see God, can see him, and those who already falsely think they can see God will remain in their blindness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that those who do not see may see and so that those who see may become blind

contextId.information: Here "blindness" is a metaphor for not knowing God's truth. AT: "If you wanted to know God's truth, you would be able to receive your sight. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If you were blind, you would have no sin

contextId.information: This is an illustration from the work of shepherds, using metaphors. The "shepherd" is a metaphor for Jesus. The "sheep" represent those who follow Jesus, and the "strangers" are the Jewish leaders, including the Pharisees, who try to deceive the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "gate" is a metaphor that means Jesus provides access into the sheepfold where God's people dwell in his presence. AT: "I am like the gate that the sheep use to enter into the sheepfold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am the gate of the sheep

contextId.information: These words are metaphors. Jesus calls those teachers "a thief and a robber" because their teachings were false, and they were trying to lead God's people while not understanding the truth. As a result, they deceived the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "gate" is a metaphor. By referring to himself as "the gate," Jesus is showing that he offers a true way to enter the kingdom of God. AT: "I myself am like that gate." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "good shepherd" is a metaphor that represents Jesus. AT: "I am like a good shepherd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The "hired servant" is a metaphor that represents the Jewish leaders and teachers. AT: "The one who is like a hired servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the word "sheep" is a metaphor that represents God's people. Like a hired servant who abandons the sheep, Jesus says that the Jewish leaders and teachers do not care for God's people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: abandons the sheep and ... does not care for the sheep

contextId.information: Here the "good shepherd" is a metaphor for Jesus. AT: "I am like a good shepherd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "flock" and "shepherd" are metaphors. All of Jesus's followers, Jews and non-Jews, will be like one flock of sheep. He will be like a shepherd who cares for all of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "sheep" is a metaphor for the followers of Jesus. AT: "not my followers" or "not my disciples"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "sheep" is a metaphor for the followers of Jesus. The metaphor of Jesus as the "shepherd" is also implied. AT: "Just as sheep obey the voice of their true shepherd, my followers heed my voice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

People who walk in the light of the day can see well and do not stumble. "Light" is a metaphor for "truth." Jesus is implying that people who live according to truth will be able to successfully do the things that God wants them to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If someone walks in the daytime, he will not stumble, because he sees by the light of this world

contextId.information: Here "a grain of wheat" or "seed" is a metaphor for Jesus' death, burial and resurrection. Just as a seed is planted and grows again into a plant that will bear much fruit, so will many people trust in Jesus after he is killed, buried, and raised back to life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies ... it will bear much fruit

contextId.information: Here "light" is a metaphor for Jesus' teachings which reveal the truth of God. To "walk in darkness" is a metaphor that means to live without God's truth. AT: "My words are like a light to you, to help you understand how to live as God wants you to. I will not be with you much longer. You need to follow my instructions while I am still with you. If you reject my words, it will be like walking in darkness and you cannot see where you are going" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The light will still be with you for a short amount of time. Walk while you have the light, so that darkness does not overtake you. He who walks in the darkness does not know where he is going

contextId.information: Here the "light" is a metaphor for Jesus' example. AT: "I have come to show the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have come as a light

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that has these possible meanings 1) "the way to God" or 2) "the one who takes people to God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a metaphor that means Jesus can give life to people. AT: "the one who can make people alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the "true vine" is a metaphor. Jesus compares himself to a vine or a vine stem. He is the source of life that causes people to live in a way that pleases God. AT: "I am like a vine that produces good fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the "branch" is a metaphor that represents each person who belongs to Jesus. God cares for them so that they will be able to live in a way that is pleasing to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He takes away every branch in me that does not bear fruit, and he prunes every branch that bears fruit so that it will bear more fruit

contextId.information: The implied metaphor here is the "clean branches" that have already been "pruned." AT: "It is as if you have already been pruned and are clean branches because you have obeyed what I have taught you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You are already clean because of the message that I have spoken to you

contextId.information: The "vine" is a metaphor that represents Jesus. The "branches" is a metaphor that represent those who trust in Jesus and belong to him. AT: "I am like a vine, and you are like branches that are attached to the vine."(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am the vine, you are the branches

contextId.information: The implied metaphor here is the fruitful branch that represents the believer who pleases God. Just as a branch that is attached to the vine will bear much fruit, those who stay joined to Jesus will do many things that please God. AT: "you will bear much fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "fruit" is a metaphor for living to please God. AT: "when you live in a way that pleases him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the word "son" is a metaphor. Jesus wants his disciple, John, to be like a son to his mother. AT: "Woman, here is the man who will act like a son to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "lambs" is a metaphor for those persons who love Jesus and follow him. AT: "Feed the people I care for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "sheep" is a metaphor that represents those who belong to Jesus and follow him. AT: "Care for the people I care for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
